title: Intelligence Office Rebuffs House Subpoena on Whistleblower Complaint
text:
The Office of the Director of National Intelligence defended on Tuesday its decision to withhold from the House Intelligence Committee details of a whistleblower’s complaint and rebuffed demands that acting intelligence director Joseph Maguire appear before the panel this week to testify.

The nature of the whistleblower’s complaint isn’t known, but the rejection of the subpoena escalates an unusual confrontation between the House panel and the intelligence director’s office, which oversees all 17 U.S. spy agencies.

Last Friday night, House Intelligence Committee Chairman Rep. Adam Schiff (D., Calif.) issued a subpoena to Mr. Maguire, seeking to force him to turn over the whistleblower’s complaint, which Mr. Schiff said the DNI’s inspector general determined to be credible and a matter of “urgent concern.”

In a letter reviewed by The Wall Street Journal, the DNI’s general counsel told Mr. Schiff the agency “has complied fully with all applicable law” in handling the whistleblower’s complaint, adding “we are disappointed” by the subpoena and demands for Mr. Maguire to testify.

The general counsel, Jason Klitenic, wrote that it would be premature, at this juncture, for Mr. Maguire to appear at a congressional hearing Thursday, as Mr. Schiff demanded. He also wrote that the DNI wouldn’t be able to turn over documents to the panel by Mr. Schiff’s Tuesday deadline because the office needed to consult with other parts of the executive branch.

The Office of the Director of National Intelligence “remains committed to working with the Committee to reach an acceptable accommodation,” he wrote.

Mr. Schiff said Tuesday night that he still expected to see Mr. Maguire on Thursday and that his committee “will take whatever steps are necessary” to make sure that the whistleblower system works.

“He needs to come in and explain not only to us but to the public why he is ignoring the plain language of the law and whether he’s being instructed to do so,” Mr. Schiff said. “So we’ll expect to see him, under subpoena if necessary, but we expect to see him.”

Mr. Schiff suggested last week that the issues divulged by the whistleblower are being withheld to protect President Trump or other administration officials.

In the letter seen by the Journal, Mr. Klitenic said the concerns raised by the unidentified whistleblower concerned conduct by someone outside the U.S. intelligence community. Because the concerns didn’t involve matters overseen by the DNI’s office, he argued, they didn’t meet the threshold of an issue of “urgent concern,” which by law would require that the complaint be transmitted to Congress.

Asked Tuesday morning about the standoff, Mark Warner, the top Democrat on the Senate Intelligence Committee, said he was aware of the issue but said “we’re going down our own path.”

“I had a great deal of confidence in Dan Coats and deputy director Sue Gordon,” Mr. Warner told The Journal, referring to Mr. Maguire’s predecessor and his deputy, who resigned last month. “I think it was our country’s loss when they were forced out. I think Maguire is trying to do a good job, but any effort to politicize our intelligence community” is of great concern.

—Dustin Volz contributed to this article.

Write to Warren P. Strobel at Warren.Strobel@wsj.com and Siobhan Hughes at siobhan.hughes@wsj.com
description: The Office of the Director of National Intelligence defended its decision to withhold from a House committee details of a whistleblower’s complaint and rebuffed demands that acting intelligence director Joseph Maguire testify.
